ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We learned about/ read key french literature throughout the past few centuries and discussed the themes and philosophical side of the course.
A broad survey into the evolution of french literature, a lot about women, femininity, dreams, memory, etc
So much (cursory) knowledge of French literature and its history
Reading, speaking, and writing in French! And overall comprehension of the language
I learned about the canon of French Literature and the history of French thought around these pieces.
We explored the history of French literature, learned how to discuss texts in French, and also received feedback on how to write French papers.
I improved my french reading and speaking skills. I also gained a much deeper knowledge of french literature and its themes over several centuries.

This course is basically a survey of French literature, so obviously you will improve your written and oral skills in French. That's said, what you put in is what you get out, so I wouldn't necessarily recommend taking it solely for the language credit. I found most of the readings very insightful and well connected with one anotherespecially enjoyed Baudelaire, Emilie du Chatelet, Voltaire, Proust, Annie Ernaux.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the readings have a wide range, the course structure is well-paced, Professor is funny and very kind 
Weaknesses: hard to engage/ not much discussion within the class, feedback was limited, I wish there was an opportunity to work on vocabulary, because I felt my reading improved but not my speaking

Strengths - Mme. Sanjabi is one of the best professors I've ever had. Weaknesses- time contraints made it such that we didn't get to talk in depth abt certain readings. also does not pull from a diverse set of francophone authors
Can't think of much that needs to be improved. Was an overall very engaging and informative course
Professor Sanjabi is an amazing professor and the book selection was great! The discussions were always interesting and work was very manageable.
This course was strong in its breadth, but sometimes lacked depth. We went through a lot of readings but it felt hard to engage with some of the writings when we only spent a day or two on them.

This course covers many different movements and periods of french literature, but I felt that some of the earlier movements were not as interesting and I also would have liked to read from a more diverse cast of authors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes it is a good course if you're pursuing the french certificate and it is good to understand and read important/ famous works. A low-stress class for the most part.
yes! it's a fun class and is really enjoyable
Yes, especially if they want to get into French literature

Yes! I absolutely loved this course and felt like my French improved a lot in all ways. I took it after L4 at Yale and a semester living in France and felt like it was a good level. I learned a lot about French literature and gained a better appreciation appreciation for it in general. Madame Sanjabi is amazing!

Yes! I loved this course.  The readings were super interesting, and I enjoyed the class discussions.  Mme Sanjabi does an excellent job of facilitating the conversation without pressuring students too much to talk.
Yes but with the caveat that students really need to be strong in their French skills and willing to participate in class.
Yes! Prof. Sanjabi is great and very engaging. Take it if you have the chance, it is a great L5 credit.
I would recommend this course to students very interested in french literature, but if they were looking primarily to improve their language skills, I would recommend a different course.

Yes! Mme Sanjabi is very sweet and clearly enjoys the works she is teaching. The class is very much discussion based, and although my section was kind of dead, I still found her opinions valuable and agreeable and appreciated the material she gave us to guide the readings. Take this class if you're interested in French Literature. The workload was also very reasonable (besides somewhat heavy readings), 2 short papers, a presentation and an oral exam.

extras.title: FREN 170 01 - Intro Study of French Lit
